body:
Thanks for the pull request, and welcome! The Rust team is excited to review your changes, and you should hear from @Aatch (or someone else) soon.

If any changes to this PR are deemed necessary, please add them as extra commits. This ensures that the reviewer can see what has changed since they last reviewed the code. Due to the way GitHub handles out-of-date commits, this should also make it reasonably obvious what issues have or haven't been addressed. Large or tricky changes may require several passes of review and changes.

Please see [the contribution instructions](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md) for more information.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30588) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30660) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
This will have to be reviewed outside-of-github because of its tendency to censor.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30676) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

I removed the eager const eval to do that on its own. For now it's just the typestrong const integers.

I'm not sure what the expected behavior of something like `160 as i8` is, but if it's "random value" instead of an error, then I can easily introduce that by turning it into `42` deterministically outside of true constants (and emitting a warning oc).
I'll run crater.
[Report](https://gist.github.com/brson/e68999bb49dd8839a0c2). Only regression is a false positive.
wooohoo xD I'll split it up into multiple PRs for easier reviewing
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30890) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
this is ready to be reviewed
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #31010) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
rebased
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #30899) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
can be reviewed in github again since I split out the const math into its own file (and crate for that matter)
Could somebody else from @rust-lang/compiler also review this?
I'd like to take a look. Trying to keep on top of constants.
r? @nikomatsakis
addressed comments
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #31410) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
Sorry for the delay. I've gotten quite the backlog. Will be reviewing soon though!

OK, I finished reviewing. I left various comments but the only important thing I think is that the handling of fn argument types seems wrong to me -- @oli-obk let me know what you think. And I apologize again for the delay, this looks like a really nice patch!
Addressed comments. Rebasing now
rebased
@bors r+

:pushpin: Commit feefc39 has been approved by `nikomatsakis`

<!-- @bors r=nikomatsakis feefc39cad8332ce13342a3d3d082b34294aaac1 -->
:hourglass: Testing commit feefc39 with merge fbc0523...
:broken_heart: Test failed - [auto-linux-64-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-64-opt/builds/8167)

So the issue is that now, since const fn's arguments aren't inferred anymore from their types, we can't call const fns in array length computations anymore, because we end up with `ConstInt::Infer`. We could then turn it into a concrete integral, but that would probably cause more problems like #23833, since the computations would be done as if it were a `u64`, but after the computation we'd squash it into the target type.

Instead I made a fix (which also improves error reporting and evades #23926 in some cases). Now, whenever we compute a constant integer, we do a few things:
1. if it's one of the concrete integral variants, check if the hint (if any) matches that type. If not -> error
2. if it's a signed uninferred integral (bc we had a negative somewhere in the computation) and the type-hint is an unsigned type -> error
3. if it's an uninferred integral and we have a type-hint, check if the integral is in the range of the type-hint and turn it into a concrete integral
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #31846) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
rebased, was just a collision in `crates.mk`
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #31430) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

> It seems to me that this strategy still ultimately relies on a type-hint -- can you spell out the scenario you were describing in a bit more detail maybe? Overall this PR looks really nice but I'm a bit concerned now that maybe I'm missing some subtle interplay around type-hints.

The fix I mentioned is just for const-fn arguments, and the bugs that occur now due to missing type inference only occur there. We can keep re-iterating const-fn since it's behind a feature gate. At least for primitive types we can get the actual types from ast-types (which we already do in const casts). We can do that for function arguments, function return types and constants' types. This should improve things a lot.

Yes we still depend on type-hints, but the type-hints are not really hints, they are concretely known types _except_ in the case of casts.

The following are the only calls to `eval_const_expr_partial` without `ExprTypeChecked` (outside of const eval recursion)

repeat count:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/librustc/middle/ty/util.rs#L336-L337
enum discriminant:
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/librustc_typeck/collect.rs#L1039-L1040
array length
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/librustc_typeck/astconv.rs#L1685-L1686

> My feeling is that in order for constant evaluation to really be used deeply in type-check, we are going probably going to have to intertwine it better into collect, so that there is a back-and-forth between constant evaluation and typing. I'm not sure it's possible for them to be strictly separated.

That would be a wonderful thing.

For now I could simply abort const evaluation in case of uncertainties (basically whenever we don't have a type-hint for a literal?) and we can see if that breaks anyones code. That would get us down to the set of constants we know we can evaluate correctly (and error otherwise). This way we can keep improving things or at least not create implicit dependencies on bugs in the const evaluator.
OK, I think I am satisfied with the state of this branch.

To be more specific: I do think our treatment of "inferred types" is a bit risky, in that we treat them "as if" they are u64 until we know more -- I feel like to be most precise, we should treat them simultaneously as all possible types, so that if we later learn that they are in fact a u8 (or whatever) we can tell if they should have panic'd earlier.

However, given the limited areas where constant eval is used w/o types being computed, I am confident we can evolve our treatment here. And I guess that most projects won't have overflows in practice anyway.

Plus, I think the status quo is equally bad :)
@bors r+

:pushpin: Commit eff6ed3 has been approved by `nikomatsakis`

<!-- @bors r=nikomatsakis eff6ed301050cffe77ce8cbac37d6b4b1f982e19 -->
:hourglass: Testing commit eff6ed3 with merge 72721a2...
:broken_heart: Test failed - [auto-linux-32-opt](http://buildbot.rust-lang.org/builders/auto-linux-32-opt/builds/8290)

hmm... I don't have a 32-bit machine here to look at these test failures closer. But it seems to me that these tests were doing weird stuff on 32-bit anyway:
- [use a 64-bit unsuffixed literal for a `usize`](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/test/run-pass/nested-vec-3.rs#L60)
  - [2nd occurence](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/test/run-pass/deriving-hash.rs#L33)
  - [3rd occurence](https://github.com/oli-obk/rust/blob/eager_const_eval2/src/test/run-pass/const-fn-val.rs#L13)
- [contrary to popular belief, using unsuffixed literals that require 64 bit in enum discriminant values does not make the enum's discriminant 64-bit](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/test/run-pass/enum-discrim-range-overflow.rs#L13-L16)
  - [2nd occurence](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/test/run-pass/enum-discrim-autosizing.rs#L44-L52)
  - [3rd occurence](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/test/run-pass/enum-discrim-width-stuff.rs#L39)

---

Actual fallout from this PR in
https://github.com/oli-obk/rust/blob/eager_const_eval2/src/test/run-pass/const-negation.rs

This is due to const casting. Simple enough to fix by applying

> At least for primitive types we can get the actual types from ast-types (which we already do in const casts for the target type). 

to getting the types when evaluating a `const` definition's value, a function argument or a function's return expression.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #31979) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.
@oli-obk the travis errors look legit

Yea, but this can't be merged anyway, since I don't know how to proceed on the above mentioned points.

I can fix the tests, but my changes would still be breaking changes on 32bit
Oh, I overlooked that last message. Let me read that more closely.

That said:

> At least for primitive types we can get the actual types from ast-types (which we already do in const casts for the target type).

As an interim step, poking at the AST when we are still doing typeck seems...tolerable, even if a hack. I imagine that when we implement something better, these cases would still work!

The full error from bors is

```

error: aborting due to 20 previous errors

------------------------------------------

thread '[run-pass] run-pass/const-negation.rs' panicked at 'explicit panic', /buildslave/rust-buildbot/slave/auto-linux-32-opt/build/src/compiletest/runtest.rs:1560
```

One example from this error is

```
const L: usize = ::std::i32::MIN as usize;
```

which yields

> error: constant evaluation error: literal out of range for usize [E0471]

because it ignored the type of `std::i32::MIN` because there was a type-hint (`usize`).

Note: this is already happening now, but not observable, because all constants are `u64`/`i64`

@oli-obk 

Those errors seem...wrong to me. In particular, [we decided](https://github.com/rust-lang/rfcs/pull/1019) that the meaning of `as` is basically ["truncate and convert bits"](https://github.com/pnkfelix/rfcs/commit/fb6d9cb937faa908d7ee8e4c037bc6cfa58202b1). So something like `i64::MIN as usize` has a defined semantics, no?

Yes, thats why i fixed them in 413b0b9

The issues with bad usize literals and enum discriminants on 32 bit systems still exists. These are probably warned about, but rpass tests allow warnings. My changes cause these warnings to be errors in constants.

> Yes, thats why i fixed them in 413b0b9

OK, so, I must be confused. I thought we were talking about fallout you did not know how to fix. The problem then is specifically literals like [this one](https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/blob/master/src/test/run-pass/nested-vec-3.rs#L60), which were permitted before but are now resulting in an error?

Were wrong sized literals _always_ permitted, or only in `usize` constants?
Always. We just warn about them. I think we only warn on usize literals if they are too big for the target.

@oli-obk I recall now that we made this decision intentionally, but was quite some time ago -- years and years ago, when we were first adding integer literal type inference (before that, you had to explicit write `22_usize` always, or else the literal defaulted to `isize`). Initially we would fail to infer if the desired type was out of range, but there were a bunch of gray cases mixed with some unrelated impl difficulties, and we decided to back off and just issue a lint. It doesn't seem like the right call to me given our current overflow rules and so forth, but it may not be something we can easily change. 

How hard would it be to match the current behavior in this PR? At minimum, I feel like I'd rather separate out the "cleanup" from the "intentional change in behavior".
I can change the code to succeed when overflowing an oob literal. Should be trivial enough. I'll add some more tests for corner cases i can think of.
:umbrella: The latest upstream changes (presumably #31710) made this pull request unmergeable. Please resolve the merge conflicts.

As the commit message of fcee002 states:

`assert_eq!(-9223372036854775808isize as u64, 0x8000000000000000);`

fails on 32 bit and succeeds on 64 bit. These commits don't change that behavior.

The following worked before my changes, because the discriminant was
always processed as `u64`.
Now it fails, because on 32 bit the discriminant of `Bu64` is now `0` instead of `-9223372036854775808`. This is more in line with the above assertion's code, since
`-9223372036854775808isize as u64` on 32 bit yielded `0`.

``` rust
enum Eu64 {
    Au64 = 0,
    Bu64 = 0x8000_0000_0000_0000
}
```
@oli-obk thanks; can't say I'm entirely happy with the rules here, but this seems like the best step for now.
@bors r+

but I added the dependencies to every crate that has `extern crate rustc_const_eval`
